channel.title: BBC News | News Front Page | World Edition
channel.description: Visit BBC News for up-to-the-minute news, breaking news, video, audio and feature stories. BBC News provides trusted World and UK news as well as local and regional perspectives. Also entertainment, business, science, technology and health news.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse

item.title: Ferry sinks in Red Sea
item.description: A ferry carrying about 1,400 people has sunk in the Red Sea, off the Egyptian coast. Bodies and survivors are being pulled from the water but the weather is hampering rescue efforts.

item.title: Muslims in new cartoon protests
item.description: Fresh protests are being made over the publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Taleban clash 'leaves many dead'
item.description: Nearly 20 people are killed in fighting between troops and Taleban in Helmand province in Afghanistan, officials say.

item.title: Iran set to face Security Council
item.description: The UN's atomic watchdog will report Iran to the Security Council when it reconvenes in Vienna, diplomats say.

item.title: Kenya gold scam report delivered
item.description: A report into Kenya's multi-million dollar gold and diamond scam is handed over to President Mwai Kibaki.

item.title: More Dutch troops for Afghanistan
item.description: The Dutch parliament approves a plan to send an extra 1,400 troops to Afghanistan.

item.title: Japan minister urges royal debate
item.description: Japan's foreign minister questions plans to let females succeed to the throne, the first Cabinet member to do so.

item.title: France deports African 'rioter'
item.description: France says it has deported a Malian man, in the first expulsion of a foreigner over the November urban riots.

item.title: Mussolini's jazz pianist son dies
item.description: Romano Mussolini, a son of Italy's former fascist dictator, dies in Rome aged 79 after a successful jazz career.

item.title: Nigeria's Christians back Muslims
item.description: A Nigerian Christian body condemns the publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: US House Republicans pick leader
item.description: US House of Representatives Republicans elect John Boehner as their leader, after their ex-chief had to quit.

item.title: Venezuela expels US naval 'spy'
item.description: Venezuelan leader Hugo Chavez says he is expelling a US official accused of spying with Venezuelan officers.

item.title: Minister quits over Thaksin deal
item.description: A Thai Cabinet minister resigns over a controversial share sale by PM Thaksin Shinawatra's family.

item.title: Jakarta joins cartoon protests
item.description: Protests over the publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad reach Indonesia.

item.title: Editor convicted for Chechen text
item.description: The editor of a US-funded newspaper in Russia is found guilty of inciting ethnic hatred over Chechnya.

item.title: Madrid backs Gas Natural takeover
item.description: The Spanish government gives final approval to Gas Natural's hostile 22.4bn takeover bid for fellow Spanish firm Endesa.

item.title: Rocket attack on Israeli kibbutz
item.description: A rocket attack in southern Israel injures three, as Israeli forces clash with Hezbollah guerrillas in Lebanon.

item.title: Palestinian men seized with bombs
item.description: Israeli forces arrest two Palestinians carrying explosive belts at a checkpoint near Nablus, the Israeli army says.

item.title: Musharraf in cartoon condemnation
item.description: Pakistani President Pervez Musharraf strongly condemns the publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet.

item.title: 'Crackdown' ahead of Dhaka rally
item.description: Bangladesh's opposition parties say 1,000 of its activists are detained ahead of an anti-government rally.

item.title: Straw condemns cartoon row press
item.description: Jack Straw attacks European papers for reprinting a cartoon of the Prophet Muhammad, but praises UK media.

item.title: US jobs growth less than forecast
item.description: The US economy added 193,000 jobs in January, while consumer sentiment dipped slightly.

item.title: Cocaine stomach problem warning
item.description: Cocaine users are at risk of life-threatening stomach problems, doctors have warned.

item.title: Infertility link in iceman's DNA
item.description: Oetzi, the prehistoric man frozen in a glacier for 5,000 years, could have been infertile, new research on his genes suggests.

item.title: 'Limited' damage from Nyxem virus
item.description: Early warnings about the destructive Nyxem virus have headed off widespread damage, say experts.

item.title: Three Irish music awards for U2
item.description: Irish rockers U2 win three prizes at the Meteor Ireland Music Awards, held in their home town of Dublin.

item.title: Football: Guinea 2-3 Senegal
item.description: Senegal come from behind to beat Guinea 3-2 and reach the semi-finals at the African Cup of Nations.

item.title: Cricket: Aussies record easy win
item.description: Brett Lee takes 4-21 as South Africa slump to an 80-run defeat against Australia in the VB Series.

channel.title: BBC News | Middle East | World Edition
channel.description: Visit BBC News for up-to-the-minute news, breaking news, video, audio and feature stories. BBC News provides trusted World and UK news as well as local and regional perspectives. Also entertainment, business, science, technology and health news.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse

item.title: Egyptian ferry sinks in Red Sea
item.description: An Egyptian ferry carrying 1,400 people sinks in the Red Sea, with reports of bodies being pulled from the sea.

item.title: Muslims in new cartoon protests
item.description: Fresh protests are being made over the publication of cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Iran set to face Security Council
item.description: The UN's atomic watchdog will report Iran to the Security Council when it reconvenes in Vienna, diplomats say.

item.title: Rocket attack on Israeli kibbutz
item.description: A rocket attack in southern Israel injures three, as Israeli forces clash with Hezbollah guerrillas in Lebanon.

item.title: Palestinians seized with bombs
item.description: Israeli forces arrest two Palestinians carrying explosive belts at a checkpoint near Nablus, the Israeli army says.

item.title: Boycott costs Danes ?1m a day
item.description: Arla Foods says the boycott of Danish products in the Middle East is costing it about ?1m a day, and ?40m to ?50m so far.

item.title: WHO confirms Iraq bird flu death
item.description: The World Health Organisation confirms a teenager died of the H5N1 strain of bird flu in Iraq last month.

item.title: Iran 'has negative role in world'
item.description: A BBC World Service poll finds Iran is the country most widely viewed as having a negative influence in the world.

item.title: German seized in W Bank freed
item.description: A German is seized and freed in the West Bank, after kidnap threats in the row over cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Blair 'made secret US Iraq pact'
item.description: Tony Blair and George Bush had already decided to invade Iraq in January 2003, a human rights lawyer claims.

item.title: US official admits Iraq aid theft
item.description: A US official in charge of administering reconstruction aid in central Iraq admits stealing millions of dollars.

item.title: Car bombings rock Baghdad
item.description: At least 10 people die and 52 are injured in car bombings at a petrol station and market in Iraq's capital.

item.title: Lebanese ministers rejoin cabinet
item.description: Ministers from Lebanon's two main Shia parties, Hezbollah and Amal, end their seven-week boycott of the cabinet.

item.title: Al-Qaeda 'still main US threat'
item.description: The US intelligence chief says al-Qaeda continues to plot terror attacks against American targets.

item.title: Hamas rejects pressure to change
item.description: A Hamas official says nothing can stop the Palestinian militant group from forming the next government.

item.title: Gaza gunmen surround EU offices
item.description: Gunmen briefly surround the EU's offices in Gaza, demanding an apology over cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad.

item.title: Saddam trial faces fresh delays
item.description: The trial of Saddam Hussein and seven others is adjourned for 11 days after no defendants appear in court.

item.title: Iran nuclear row 'not a crisis'
item.description: The UN's nuclear body says the row over Iran's nuclear research is reaching a critical phase but is not a crisis.

item.title: Explosion in Gaza raises tension
item.description: An explosion rocks the house of a former security Palestinian chief and senior Fatah party member in Gaza.

item.title: Palestinians 'face budget crisis'
item.description: The World Bank warns that the Palestinian Authority's budget has become increasingly unsustainable.

item.title: Israel halts tax payments to PA
item.description: Israel says it is suspending tax and customs duty payments to the Palestinians, after Hamas' election win.

item.title: Europe press join cartoon row
item.description: European papers reprint controversial caricatures of the Prophet Muhammad, defying Muslim outrage.

item.title: Israelis split over outpost clash
item.description: Newspapers in Israel are split over the use of force to evacuate the Amona outpost in the West Bank.

item.title: Programmes and schedules
After elections: Palestinian views
item.description: The BBC News website speaks to six Palestinians about the surprise results of their parliamentary elections.

item.title: Iran crisis: Global reaction
item.description: A selection of the thousands of emails from around the world sent to the BBC in reaction to the ongoing Iran nuclear crisis.

item.title: Hamas win sparks soul-searching
item.description: The BBC's Jim Muir looks at the background to the poll success of Palestinian militants, Hamas, that caught the world by surprise.

item.title: Divided Iraqis judge Saddam trial
item.description: Ordinary Iraqis give their verdict on the ups and downs of Saddam's trial

item.title: A piece of railway history
item.description: Malcolm Billings traces the route of the forgotten Hejaz Railway, built 100 years ago to carry pilgrims from Istanbul to Medina.

channel.title: Comments on: A chance for a Middle East peace
channel.description: Comments on MetaFilter post A chance for a Middle East peace

item.title: A chance for a Middle East peace
item.dc:creator: homunculus

item.title: By: CunningLinguist
item.description:
The Syria stuff is fascinating, but of course the bit that's getting all the attention is this:
"The Obama transition team also helped persuade Israel to end the bombing of Gaza and to withdraw its ground troops before the Inauguration. According to the former senior intelligence official, who has access to sensitive information, “Cheney began getting messages from the Israelis about pressure from Obama” when he was President-elect. Cheney, who worked closely with the Israeli leadership in the lead-up to the Gaza ar, portrayed Obama to the Israelis as a “pro-Palestinian,” who would not support their efforts (and, in private, disparaged Obama, referring to him at one point as someone who would “never make it in the major leagues”)."
item.dc:creator: CunningLinguist

item.title: By: Astro Zombie
item.description: Cheney, who worked closely with the Israeli leadership in the lead-up to the Gaza ar, portrayed Obama to the Israelis as a “pro-Palestinian,” who would not support their efforts (and, in private, disparaged Obama, referring to him at one point as someone who would “never make it in the major leagues”)." Yeah, fuck that guy.
item.dc:creator: Astro Zombie

item.title: By: netbros
item.description: Who's zoomin' who?
item.dc:creator: netbros

item.title: By: Mitrovarr
item.description: Cheney, who worked closely with the Israeli leadership in the lead-up to the Gaza ar... You know, the idea that the Israelis would work closely with and be friendly toard Cheney is one of the most damaging allegations I've heard about them. Way to consort with evil, guys.
item.dc:creator: Mitrovarr

item.title: By: shothotbot
item.description: Typically good, 40 minute Fresh Air interview with Seymour Hersh from today.
item.dc:creator: shothotbot

item.title: By: netbros
item.description: The Hersh article was featured on the Rachel Maddow Show tonight on MSNBC. Video clips will be available in the morning.
item.dc:creator: netbros

item.title: By: homunculus
item.description: Here are a couple of clips of Hersh on CNN today: CNN - Seymour Hersh - Israel-Syria peace prospects; Cheney interferes with Obama détente? CNN - Seymour Hersh - Cheney's JSOC hit squad(s) update
item.dc:creator: homunculus

item.title: By: atchafalaya
item.description: I still think Hersh was misled by Cheney et al into writing those stories about how we were going to invade Iran. Maybe that's why Hersh still has it in for them. Not that he would need an excuse. Still, I was hoping the Fresh Air interview would at least touch on that; what does he say about those stories now?
item.dc:creator: atchafalaya

item.title: By: Blazecock Pileon
item.description: Hersh kept us out of Iran. Every American owes him a debt of gratitude.
item.dc:creator: Blazecock Pileon

item.title: By: srboisvert
item.description: Cheney, who worked closely with the Israeli leadership in the lead-up to the Gaza ar... Normally "WTF?" is a rhetorical question. Every now and then it gets an answer. Cheney is the fuck. Seriously. The dude is the anti-strategist. He is Opposite Man.
item.dc:creator: srboisvert

item.title: By: homunculus
item.description: I still think Hersh was misled by Cheney et al into writing those stories about how we were going to invade Iran. My feeling is that he was accurately reporting on what Cheney et al wanted to do, but were never able to do. I have little doubt that the plans were in place. Hersh kept us out of Iran. I think it's more like circumstances in Iraq kept us from hitting Iran. If Iraq had gone as smoothly as Cheney and Rumsfeld thought it was going to, I don't think Hersh's articles would have kept the Bush administration from launching a strike. But as things kept getting worse, there was less and less will to open another front, and that last NIE was the final nail in the coffin. Hersh deserves credit for his reporting, but I don't think he single-handedly prevented another ar. We'll probably never know for sure.
item.dc:creator: homunculus

item.title: By: homunculus
item.description: And speaking of circumstances in Iraq, Iraq: the unraveling?
item.dc:creator: homunculus

item.title: By: homunculus
item.description: Netanyahu to Obama: Stop Iran—Or I Will
item.dc:creator: homunculus

item.title: By: flapjax at midnite
item.description: Hersh kept us out of Iran. Perhaps a bit of an oversimplification. Tell you one thing though: Ol' Dick Nixon kept our boys out of Northern Ireland, and for that we owe him plenty. Speaking of Syria, though, I recommend europic's flickr sets for an interesting and intimate look at the country from street level.
item.dc:creator: flapjax at midnite

item.title: By: Heliochrome85
item.description: Sy Hersh might be the most credible journalist in print today. Like the above posters, I have no doubt that the plans were in place, but forced to be tabled because of current political situation. Having lived in Syria for a third of my life (4 months a year, every year), i can say the country is ripe for US contact. It is not the same Syria as was under his father. The Golan Heights are still a sticking point, but the population as a whole want to reach a peaceful solution with Israel. I have significantly more pictures from my travels than Europic, on flickr... Syria 2008 Syria 2006 Syria 2004 Syria 2003
item.dc:creator: Heliochrome85

item.title: By: homunculus
item.description: Countdown: Seymour Hersh on the Dick Cheney "Stay Behinds"
item.dc:creator: homunculus

item.title: By: homunculus
item.description: Israel's new ultra-nationalist foreign minister has said it is not bound by a US-sponsored 2007 agreement to reach a peace deal with the Palestinians.
item.dc:creator: homunculus

item.title: Infertility link in iceman's DNA
item.description: Oetzi, the prehistoric man frozen in a glacier for 5,000 years, may have been infertile, research suggests.

item.title: Distant world tops Pluto for size
item.description: New observations confirm an icy, rocky world in the distant reaches of the Solar System is bigger than Pluto.

item.title: Rat brain 'can smell in stereo'
item.description: Rats can home in on smells using a method similar to the stereo processing of sounds, scientists say.

item.title: Bites spread fatal 'devil' cancer
item.description: Facial tumours that have killed thousands of Tasmanian devils could be spread by the animals biting each other.

item.title: Whitehall in greenhouse gas row
item.description: UK government departments cannot agree on setting greenhouse gas limits for businesses, the BBC learns.

item.title: GM aid for pandemic flu vaccine
item.description: Scientists have used genetic modification in an early step towards creating a vaccine for bird flu.

item.title: Smaller firms could trade carbon
item.description: Small and medium-sized firms may face pollution limits in the UK's drive to cut carbon dioxide emissions.

item.title: Smallest fish compete for honours
item.description: When is the smallest really the smallest? When it comes to fish, the answer is just not clear-cut.

item.title: Concern over 'spare part' babies
item.description: Children created as "saviour siblings" to aid a sick brother or sister must be monitored to ensure their wellbeing, experts suggest.

item.title: Korea cloning expert questioned
item.description: Disgraced scientist Hwang Woo-suk is questioned by officials for the first time since admitting his work was faked.

item.title: Gene makes earwax wet or dry
item.description: Whether your earwax is wet or dry is determined by a mutation in a single gene, scientists have discovered.

item.title: Ricin vaccine 'shown to be safe'
item.description: A vaccine against the deadly toxin ricin is safe and effective, a US study has shown.

item.title: Britons unconvinced on evolution
item.description: A little under half of Britons in a poll accept evolution theory as the best description for the development of life.

item.title: Bird groups hopeful on vultures
item.description: The Indian government awaits final tests before deciding what to do about a drug linked to vulture deaths.

item.title: Print 'proof' of big cat presence
item.description: Police in Fife believe they have the first conclusive proof that the "Beast of Balbirnie" exists.

item.title: Stark warning on climate change
item.description: Greenhouse gas emissions are rising at an "unsustainable" rate and the Greenland ice cap is at risk, scientists say.

item.title: Nations back elephant action plan
item.description: Nations with wild populations of Asian elephants meet for the first time to consider how to protect the species.

item.title: Sea level rise 'is accelerating'
item.description: Global sea-levels could rise by about 30cm by the end of this century if current trends continue, a study warns.

item.title: In upset, Boehner selected House majority leader
item.description: In an upset, House Republicans selected Rep. John Boehner of Ohio for their new majority leader Thursday. Boehner beat Rep. Roy Blunt, the acting majority leader and the leading candidate going into today, by a vote of 122 to 109 on the second round of voting.

item.title: Ship with 1,400 sinks in Red Sea; 100 people rescued
item.description: An aging Egyptian passenger ferry loaded to near capacity with about 1,400 people and dozens of vehicles sank today in the Red Sea, an official said. Egyptian maritime officials told state-run Nile TV that 100 survivors had been rescued. At least 100 bodies have been recovered, Egyptian officials said. The ship had disappeared at midnight from radar screens, said Adel Shoukri, a spokesman for the El Salam Maritime Transport Co.

item.title: Jobless Rate Falls to Lowest Level in 4 Years
item.description: Employment was up in virtually every sector of the economy and the country as a whole added 193,000 jobs, the Labor Department reported.
item.author: VIKAS BAJAJ

item.title: Pension Battle May Entangle Mogul's Home
item.description: Ira L. Rennert's oceanfront estate may be seized to make sure he delivers on pensions promised to a group of steelworkers in Ohio.
item.author: MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

item.title: Gains Seen in Redesign of S.U.V.'s
item.description: Deaths fell by nearly half when S.U.V.'s were lowered by as little as half an inch or equipped with impact-absorbing bars below the bumpers.
item.author: JEREMY W. PETERS

item.title: After Dreary '05, Drug Makers See Brighter Year Ahead
item.description: Drug companies say they are filling their pipelines with promising new treatments, and prescription growth seems to be accelerating slightly, as well.
item.author: ALEX BERENSON

item.title: Device Maker Moves to Appease the F.D.A.
item.description: The F.D.A. cited quality-control problems and inadequate responses to earlier warnings at factories operated by Boston Scientific.
item.author: BARNABY J. FEDER

item.description: A grand jury indicted three former executives of General Re and one former executive of A.I.G. with charges of fraud and conspiracy.
item.author: JENNY ANDERSON

item.title: Senate Approves Legislation Cutting Taxes by $70 Billion
item.description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP) — The Senate passed $70 billion in tax cuts on Thursday, one step in an effort that Republican leaders hope will preserve President Bush's tax reductions for capital gains and dividends.
item.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Amazon's Profit Fell 43% in Its 4th Quarter
item.description: Amazon reported lower than expected revenue along with much higher expenses, but blamed the profit drop on a reduced tax benefit.
item.author: LAURIE J. FLYNN

item.title: Witness Says Enron Hid Huge Loss From Investors
item.description: A witness said former Enron chief executives boasted about the retail energy services unit but failed to mention losses there to investors or employees.
item.author: ALEXEI BARRIONUEVO

item.title: Net Income Declines 69% in Fourth Quarter at Comcast
item.description: The nation's largest cable company said profits slid because investment losses and a higher tax rate offset gains in its core businesses.
item.author: KEN BELSON

item.title: Retail Sales Increased 5% in January
item.description: Retailers reported their biggest monthly sales gain since June as shoppers redeemed gift cards and bought spring fashions.
item.author: REUTERS

item.title: Loral Names New Chief
item.description: Loral Space and Communications named its vice chairman, Michael B. Targoff, to take over as chief executive in March.
item.author: BLOOMBERG NEWS

item.title: Productivity Rose More Slowly in '05; Wages Rose More Quickly
item.description: The combination of slowing productivity and rising labor costs could set off inflation, and is expected to attract the attention of the Federal Reserve.
item.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.description: G.M. said it will outsource up to $15 billion of information technology work to several companies in an attempt to cut costs.
item.author: JEREMY W. PETERS

item.description: The European Central Bank hinted at a rate increase next month, citing Europe's continuing growth and the ongoing threat of inflation.
item.author: MARK LANDLER

item.author: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

channel.title: NYT > Movie Reviews
channel.description: Find movie reviews & breaking news on actors & actresses, studios, Hollywood, DVD & Video, Oscars, new releases, independent film, movie trailers, showtimes, movie tickets.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2006 The New York Times Company

item.title: Movie Review | 'Something New': Physical Passion That Conquers All
item.description: In this pleasantly diverting romance about a black woman and a white man forced to transcend prejudice, the chemistry between the leads is as unmistakable as the setup is contrived.
item.author: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Celebrating Boris Karloff, the Monster and the Man
item.description: Film Forum is celebrating the 75th anniversary of "Frankenstein" with a weeklong retrospective devoted to the odd career of its unlikely star, Boris Karloff.
item.author: TERRENCE RAFFERTY

item.title: Movie Review | 'A Good Woman': A Hollywood Adaptation of an Oscar Wilde Play: At Sea on the Italian Coast in 1930
item.description: This misbegotten adaptation of Oscar Wilde’s 1892 comedy "Lady Windermere’s Fan" lacks Wilde's high-toned repartee.
item.author: STEPHEN HOLDEN

item.title: Movie Review | 'The Tenants': For Two Competing Writers, Race Is the Great Divide
item.description: The message about race relations in America conveyed by this choppy and psychologically cauterized screen adaptation of Bernard Malamud's 1971 novel is dire.
item.author: STEPHEN HOLDEN

item.title: Movie Review | 'The Night of Truth': Building a Country on Corpses
item.description: The debut feature of the director Fanta Régina Nacro, "The Night of Truth" is a raw, Shakespearean fable that powerfully reflects the tragedy of countless civil conflicts.
item.author: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: Movie Review | 'Tamara': You Know What Happens When You Pick on the Weird Chick?
item.description: A low-budget horror film with even lower ambitions, "Tamara" is a movie of few innovations but one genuine, if unintentional, surprise.
item.author: NATHAN LEE

item.title: Movie Review | 'Blossoms of Fire': A Utopian Vision of a Matriarchal Society
item.description: Maureen Gosling's documentary aims to demythologize the Zapotec people of Juchitán, a town on the Isthmus of Tehuantepec in southeastern Mexico.
item.author: DANA STEVENS

item.title: Movie Review | 'The Tollbooth': Coming of Age in a Strange Land
item.description: In "The Tollbooth," 22-year-old Sarabeth Cohen (Marla Sokoloff), a self-described "feminist artist," talks us through the travails of her Jewish-American family and her own coming of age.
item.author: JEANNETTE CATSOULIS

item.title: Movie Review | 'Who Gets to Call It Art?': New York's Art Scene in the 60's and a Major Player Within It
item.description: Clocking in at 80 minutes, this glib, largely uninformative and poorly organized précis of the post-World War II art scene succeeds neither as history nor as art history.
item.author: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: 'Accidental Genius: How John Cassavetes Invented American Independent Film,' by Marshall Fine: Under His Influence
item.description: The film and TV critic for Star magazine has written the first genuine biography of this increasingly influential figure.
item.author: Review by PHILLIP LOPATE

item.title: Movie Review | 'Tristram Shandy: A Cock and Bull Story': An Unfilmable Book, Now Made Into a Movie
item.description: Michael Winterbottom's cheeky postmodern romp is not a movie version of Laurence Sterne's book but rather a movie about a movie about the book.
item.author: A. O. SCOTT

item.title: Movie Review | 'Bubble': A Bare-Bones Story of Romance, Jealousy and Murder at a Small-Town Doll Factory
item.description: Steven Soderbergh's willfully perverse excursion into experimentation is a rigorously minimalist story about three factory workers in a small Ohio town.
item.author: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Movie Review | 'Manderlay': An America Where Gangsters Free Slaves Not Keen for Liberation
item.description: Those willing to endure the director Lars von Trier's scorn are in for a bracing satire of the legacy of slavery in the United States.
item.author: STEPHEN HOLDEN

item.title: Movie Review | 'The Spirit of the Beehive': Sorrowful Knowledge and Startled Innocence in Franco's Spain
item.description: Víctor Erice's extraordinary 1973 film takes place at the particular intersection of reality and fantasy defined by youthful moviegoing.
item.author: A. O. SCOTT

item.title: Movie Review | 'Annapolis': Punch 'Em Like Men, You Plebes
item.description: "Annapolis" is so gung-ho about the United States Naval Academy’s ability to turn boys into fighting men it could easily be confused with a military recruiting film.
item.author: STEPHEN HOLDEN

item.title: Movie Review | 'Nanny McPhee': Using Her Own Kind of Magic to Keep the Children in Line
item.description: In this endearing but somewhat scatterbrained British film, Emma Thompson creates an indelible character reminiscent of the pre-Disney Mary Poppins.
item.author: STEPHEN HOLDEN

item.title: Movie Review | 'Roving Mars': From Earth to Mars, and All Points in Between
item.description: Mars. Imax. If you want to grow up to be an astronaut, prepare to bliss out.
item.author: NATHAN LEE

item.title: Movie Review | 'Big Momma's House 2': Secret Agent Grandma
item.description: Martin Lawrence is back in fat-lady drag in this inconsequential sequel for the undemanding moviegoer.
item.author: ANITA GATES

item.title: Movie Review | 'Imagine Me & You': In Love, Sometimes One Thing Leads Very Slowly to Another
item.description: This story about same-sex lovers up against the odds, their histories and the world will soon be gathering dust on the shelves of video stores.
item.author: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Movie Review | 'La Petite Jerusalem': Sisters in a Paris Enclave, Headed in Different Directions
item.description: In her sensitive but overly schematic debut feature, the writer-director Karin Albou reflects on the lives of two women living in an orthodox Jewish enclave in Paris.
item.author: NATHAN LEE

item.title: Movie Review | 'Breaking News': Cops, Robbers and the Thrill of the Hunt
item.description: Directed by the prolific Hong Kong action master Johnnie To, "Breaking News" is a film filled with terrifically choreographed action and very little on its mind.
item.author: MANOHLA DARGIS

channel.title: NYT > National
channel.description: Find breaking news and multimedia on health care, The Supreme Court, NASA, politics and government, taxes, the White House, education and business.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2006 The New York Times Company

item.title: New Orleans Facing Election and New Order
item.description: Mitch Landrieu is expected to announce any day his entry into a mayoral race that will help define a radically reshaped city.
item.author: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Being a Patient: When Trust in Doctors Erodes, Other Treatments Fill the Void
item.description: In ways large and small, millions of people are taking active steps to venture outside the mainstream of traditional health care.
item.author: BENEDICT CAREY

item.title: In Mine Country, Tears, Anguish and a Brief Pause for Safety
item.description: Two fatal accidents on Wednesday brought West Virginia's mine-death toll for the year to 16.
item.author: IAN URBINA

item.title: King Funeral Has Surprise in Site Choice
item.description: Coretta Scott King's funeral will be held at a large suburban megachurch where her youngest daughter is an elder.
item.author: BRENDA GOODMAN

item.title: Teenager Attacks Three Men at Gay Bar in Massachusetts
item.description: An 18-year-old, armed with a hatchet and handgun, opened fire inside a gay bar early Thursday, seriously injuring three people.
item.author: KATIE ZEZIMA

item.title: Woman in California Postal Shootings Had History of Bizarre Behavior
item.description: In Grants, N.M., Nobody knew where Jennifer San Marco came from or what she was doing there, but they knew there was something wrong.
item.author: DAN FROSCH

channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.description: Find breaking news, science news & multimedia on biology, space, the environment, health, NASA, weather, drugs, heart disease, cancer, AIDS, mental health and animals.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2006 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Energy Work, One Hand Giveth and the Other Taketh
item.description: The goals of President Bush and Congress differ in ways that compete for research dollars and are costing some government researchers their jobs.
item.author: MATTHEW L. WALD

item.title: Icy Ball Is Larger Than Pluto. So, Is It a Planet?
item.description: The discovery of 2003 UB313 has intensified a debate over the definition of a planet, which has swirled about Pluto since the late 1990's.
item.author: KENNETH CHANG

item.title: Behind Bush's New Stress on Science, Lobbying by Republican Executives
item.description: Industry officials eager to see a greater government commitment to research held a series of discussions with administration officials late last year.
item.author: JOHN MARKOFF

item.title: Education: More Training Is Seen as Key to Improving Math Levels
item.description: President Bush's proposal to increase the ranks of advanced teachers in math and science does not envision hiring new teachers.
item.author: DIANA JEAN SCHEMO

item.title: How to Listen for the Sound of Plutonium
item.description: Knowing, with precision, when a country is about to gain the ability to build an atomic bomb is a problem Washington has faced for decades.
item.author: DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Essay: A Genius Finds Inspiration in the Music of Another
item.description: Albert Einstein was fascinated by Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart and sensed an affinity between their creative processes.
item.author: ARTHUR I. MILLER

channel.title: NYT > Week in Review
channel.description: Find news, essays and opinion on politics, the President of the United States, international relations, new trends & ideas, the public editor and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2005 The New York Times Company

item.title: The World: A Little Democracy or a Genie Unbottled
item.description: Free and fair elections in the Middle East have unleashed political forces that can hardly be seen as friendly to the United States.
item.author: JAMES GLANZ

item.title: Ex-Ex-Ex-Men: The Remarrying Kind
item.description: Why do the ultrarich marry, and re-marry, and re-marry?
item.author: KATE ZERNIKE

item.title: The Nation: Putting the Motor City Back in Gear
item.description: Whether retreat or rout, what can be done to reverse the fortunes of Detroit's Big Three? Five auto industry analysts tried to answer that question.
item.author: PETER EDIDIN

item.title: Ideas & Trends: Benedict: A Man of His Words
item.description: Are words enough in a papacy? Do the words themselves constitute a plan? Is it simply still too early to judge the reign of Pope Benedict XVI?
item.author: IAN FISHER

item.title: Ideas & Trends: Talk to the Rock, and Other Spy Tricks
item.description: In our digital age, isn't there something anachronistic about spies who sneak into the woods to service their pet rocks?
item.author: SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Laugh Lines: Jay Leno, David Letterman and Jon Stewart
item.description: Jay Leno.

item.title: The Nation: The New Corporate Outsourcing
item.description: Over time, Big Business has learned how to love Big Government. Or at least some of it.
item.author: CLIFFORD J. LEVY

item.title: Correspondence | The Endless Boot Camp: Playing Den Mother to a Fledgling Iraqi Army
item.description: The pace of an eventual withdrawal of more than 140,000 American troops depends on the training of the Iraq Army.
item.author: ROGER COHEN

item.title: The Basics: How to Outwit the World's Internet Censors
item.description: The Chinese government is unmatched in its ability to censor and monitor its citizens online. Of course, no system is perfect.
item.author: TOM ZELLER Jr.

item.title: The Basics: A New Leader in Canada Means...
item.description: How much of a difference will the change in government make to the United States? Probably, not a whole lot.
item.author: CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Reading File: Pitching Values to Democrats as a Way to Win
item.description: In
item.author: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Reading File: God Save Amadeus
item.description: Stephen Brown, writing in The Times Literary Supplement in London, compared Mozart to a Sex Pistol.
item.author: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: The World: How Hamas Rose From Wild Card to Power
item.description: From the start, Hamas has been a wild card in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict.
item.author: JOHN KIFNER

item.title: The World: Guess Who Likes the G.I.'s in Iraq (Look in Iran's Halls of Power)
item.description: In conversations about the nuclear showdown with the U.S. and Europe, Iranian officials cite the Iraq war as a factor Iran can play to its own advantage.
item.author: MICHAEL SLACKMAN
